Problem:
Given a linear system governed by the differential equation \( \dot{x} = Mx \), where \( M \) is a constant matrix, consider examining the impact of the linear transformation \( T(x) = Qx \) for a matrix \( Q \). We investigate how this affects the system across different time points.

If \( T(x) \) is applied to a vector \( x_0 \) at t = 0, and then allowed to evolve under \( \dot{x} = Mx \) without further intervention, will \( x(t) \) at t = T be the same as if \( x_0 \) was directly evolved to t = T under \( \dot{x} = Mx \)?
Explanation: The application of \( T(x) \) alters the initial condition to \( Qx_0 \). The solution to the differential equation starting from \( Qx_0 \) at t = 0 would evolve differently compared to starting from \( x_0 \), unless \( Q \) commutes with \( e^{Mt} \), which is generally not the case.
